Vox Populi
On several occasions in the past the News-Letter has
advocated the opening of Honor Commission administrative and policy meetings to the press as well as the individual student. In the main it has done this quietly
and without excessive publitity and in each case has met
with utter failure.
At this moment the student has no idea what plans,
if any, the Commission is considering as possible amendmentS to the present Code or as changes in the policy of
the entire Honor System. There is no reasonable advantage for this secrecy.' Quite to the contrary, given the
far-reaching effects that an Honor Commission decision
can have on an individual student, and given the theory
that the Code is self-imposed by the student, there should
be adequate means for the dissemination of information
on policy, discussions and proposals which now are carried
on behind closed doors.
It is a contractual right of every student to know
not only the final refined product of Commission meetings, but also the reasons and arguments which led to it.
The student should know so that he may discuss
with a degree of intelligence the possible ramifications of
the proposals. One may raise the objection that he has
this power now, given the plebisite necessary for ratification. This is true, but now-he has no way of taking part
in the refining process.
Informed public opinion and debate will exert a positive influence on the proceedings of the Commission and
will give that body a broader base for its decisions, and
will give the student more than a "yes or no" alternative
at the polls.
Our opponents may argue that open meetings would
lead to a cumbersome and, therefore, weak Honor System.
However, if it can be proven not cumbersome the 'threat
of weakness can be dismissed. If the Commission would
only allow outside injection under prescribed rules, the
weakness of cumbersomeness would be absolved while
maintaining the students right to know and to effect
policy through formation of public opinion.

IFB Obligations
Although the IFB has survived the rush season with
apparently little dirty ,rushing—a few minor, violations
were unreported, a lesser number of major violations were
ignored, and one major violation was punished swiftly and
stringently—and thus seems to have corrected its prior
ineffectiveness and to have instituted a real binding power
among the member- fraternities, its problems are still
many.
The major problem, and one which, because it is
intangible and not susceptible of legislation, will be the
most difficult to resolve, is that .of University-fraternity
relationships,, a matter of attitude, a matter of the fraternities' failure to identify their problems with the University. Too frequently, fraternities are wont to maintain
that their drinking, noise-making and rushing period and
techniques have nothing to do with the University, when,
in fact, the University's reputation suffers from Greek
antics and the University's freshmen are subjected to too
much rushing pressure and anxiety at entirely the wrong
time in their four years, the first four weeks (a period
of time which merely compounds the pressure and anxiety
of the previous six4eek rush period).
Rules regulating the establishment of an attitude
commensurate with the University's best interests and
with the undefined and undefinable platitudes of the
Gentleman's Code are futile, ridiculous and, indeed, totally
undesirable. But attitudes of identification with the University among fraternities are neither futile in their results, ridiculous in their conduct nor undesirable.
The admission of ZBT; the seating of presidents in
the IFB; the correction of the anxieties and pressures
on freshmen devolving from a four-week rush period,
and the establishment of continuity in IFB membership
from one year to another are issues which the IFB is
obligated to consider and act wisely upon. They are'more
important than the awarding of trophies for public
relations purposes.

Gift From Dr. Lord
Dr. and Mrs. Mason F. Lord
will present their art collection
to the university for the use of
the Department of Fine Arts,
said Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower.
President of the_ university, today.
The collection, built up by Dr.
Lord during his travels in many
parts of the world, was planned
as a aid to the teaching of fine
arts.
It contains sculpture, painting,
bronzes, drawings, prints and
works in other media and represents periods of art from 3000
B:C. to the present time.
Original Art Objects
Among the works is a rare
Sumerian head, a Greek torso,
Lombard jewelry, a 14th century
saint, woodcuts of the late
Gothic and Renaissance eras,
works by Durer and Rembrandt,
a Degas drawing, a bronze statuette by Henry Moore, a mobile
by Alexander Calder and woodcuts of Rousault and Picasso
with the original wood blocks
from which the wood cuts were
printed.
In offering the collection to
Johns Hopkins, Dr. Lord said,
"Current plans for the teaching
of art to graduate and undergraduate students at Johns Hopkins and Goucher College in cooperation with the Baltimore
Museum of Art and The Walters
Art Gallery is one of the most
stimulating cultural developments in Baltimore, and Mrs.
Lord and I are happy to have an
opportunity to contribute to its
full realization."
• Goucher, Too
In addition tb the fine collections in Baltimore Museums,
Hopkins and Goucher need art
objects of the finest quality to
round out their teaching facilities. While our gift is to the
Hopkins, we are pleased to know
that, because of the fine cooperation between the two institutions, Goucher students will
benefit from it.. too."
Dr. Lord referred to the plan
announced last year whereby
both Hopkins and Goucher will
have departments of fine arts,
with members of the faculties
eligible for joint appointments

in the two institutions. Teaching faculties in both schools will
be augmented by distinguished
members of the Baltimore Museum of Art and the Walters Art
Gallery staffs who will be appointed as part-time faculty lecturers.
New Chairman
The plan received new impetus
recently when Dr. Adolf Katzenellenbogen .upon joining the faculty of Hopkins as chairman
of the Department of Art, gave
the plan his strong support.
Commenting on the gift Dr.
Katzenellenbogen said, "It will
provide the students a rare opportunity of experiencing in the
classroom the very characteristics of original works of art, of
different stylistic aims and various media."
In notifying Johns Hopkins of
the gift, Dr. and Mrs. Lord said
that they would contribute por-

tions of the collection in keeping with the university's ability
to display the objects, and as
they can be best adapted for the
teaching needs of the Departmerit of Fine Arts.
Doctor Lord said, "As the collection is used we hope to learn
exactly what art works should
be added so that the collection
can make the greatest contribution to the teaching of the humantties.
Permanent Name
Dr. Eisenhower stated that the
gift would be known permanently as the Dr. and Mrs. Mason
F. Lord Art Collection. "The
trustees and faculties and staff
of the university are deeply
grateful to Dr. and Mrs. Lord
for their generous contribution,
and for the continuing desire to
strengthen the fine arts here and
in the Baltimore community.
Our physical facilities for displaying this rare collection are
now woefully inadequate, but I
trust the time will come when
it, and additions to it, can be
displayed properly, not only for
students, but also for the enjoyment of the general public."

Vox Populi
On several occasions in the past the News-Letter has
advocated the opening of Honor Commission administrative and policy meetings to the press as well as the individual student. In the main it has done this quietly
and without excessive publitity and in each case has met
with utter failure.
At this moment the student has no idea what plans,
if any, the Commission is considering as possible amendmentS to the present Code or as changes in the policy of
the entire Honor System. There is no reasonable advantage for this secrecy.' Quite to the contrary, given the
far-reaching effects that an Honor Commission decision
can have on an individual student, and given the theory
that the Code is self-imposed by the student, there should
be adequate means for the dissemination of information
on policy, discussions and proposals which now are carried
on behind closed doors.
It is a contractual right of every student to know
not only the final refined product of Commission meetings, but also the reasons and arguments which led to it.
The student should know so that he may discuss
with a degree of intelligence the possible ramifications of
the proposals. One may raise the objection that he has
this power now, given the plebisite necessary for ratification. This is true, but now-he has no way of taking part
in the refining process.
Informed public opinion and debate will exert a positive influence on the proceedings of the Commission and
will give that body a broader base for its decisions, and
will give the student more than a "yes or no" alternative
at the polls.
Our opponents may argue that open meetings would
lead to a cumbersome and, therefore, weak Honor System.
However, if it can be proven not cumbersome the 'threat
of weakness can be dismissed. If the Commission would
only allow outside injection under prescribed rules, the
weakness of cumbersomeness would be absolved while
maintaining the students right to know and to effect
policy through formation of public opinion.

IFB Obligations
Although the IFB has survived the rush season with
apparently little dirty ,rushing—a few minor, violations
were unreported, a lesser number of major violations were
ignored, and one major violation was punished swiftly and
stringently—and thus seems to have corrected its prior
ineffectiveness and to have instituted a real binding power
among the member- fraternities, its problems are still
many.
The major problem, and one which, because it is
intangible and not susceptible of legislation, will be the
most difficult to resolve, is that .of University-fraternity
relationships,, a matter of attitude, a matter of the fraternities' failure to identify their problems with the University. Too frequently, fraternities are wont to maintain
that their drinking, noise-making and rushing period and
techniques have nothing to do with the University, when,
in fact, the University's reputation suffers from Greek
antics and the University's freshmen are subjected to too
much rushing pressure and anxiety at entirely the wrong
time in their four years, the first four weeks (a period
of time which merely compounds the pressure and anxiety
of the previous six4eek rush period).
Rules regulating the establishment of an attitude
commensurate with the University's best interests and
with the undefined and undefinable platitudes of the
Gentleman's Code are futile, ridiculous and, indeed, totally
undesirable. But attitudes of identification with the University among fraternities are neither futile in their results, ridiculous in their conduct nor undesirable.
The admission of ZBT; the seating of presidents in
the IFB; the correction of the anxieties and pressures
on freshmen devolving from a four-week rush period,
and the establishment of continuity in IFB membership
from one year to another are issues which the IFB is
obligated to consider and act wisely upon. They are'more
important than the awarding of trophies for public
relations purposes.

Hopkins Receives Art
Gift From Dr. Lord
Dr. and Mrs. Mason F. Lord
will present their art collection
to the university for the use of
the Department of Fine Arts,
said Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower.
President of the_ university, today.
The collection, built up by Dr.
Lord during his travels in many
parts of the world, was planned
as a aid to the teaching of fine
arts.
It contains sculpture, painting,
bronzes, drawings, prints and
works in other media and represents periods of art from 3000
B:C. to the present time.
Original Art Objects
Among the works is a rare
Sumerian head, a Greek torso,
Lombard jewelry, a 14th century
saint, woodcuts of the late
Gothic and Renaissance eras,
works by Durer and Rembrandt,
a Degas drawing, a bronze statuette by Henry Moore, a mobile
by Alexander Calder and woodcuts of Rousault and Picasso
with the original wood blocks
from which the wood cuts were
printed.
In offering the collection to
Johns Hopkins, Dr. Lord said,
"Current plans for the teaching
of art to graduate and undergraduate students at Johns Hopkins and Goucher College in cooperation with the Baltimore
Museum of Art and The Walters
Art Gallery is one of the most
stimulating cultural developments in Baltimore, and Mrs.
Lord and I are happy to have an
opportunity to contribute to its
full realization."
• Goucher, Too
In addition tb the fine collections in Baltimore Museums,
Hopkins and Goucher need art
objects of the finest quality to
round out their teaching facilities. While our gift is to the
Hopkins, we are pleased to know
that, because of the fine cooperation between the two institutions, Goucher students will
benefit from it.. too."
Dr. Lord referred to the plan
announced last year whereby
both Hopkins and Goucher will
have departments of fine arts,
with members of the faculties
eligible for joint appointments

in the two institutions. Teaching faculties in both schools will
be augmented by distinguished
members of the Baltimore Museum of Art and the Walters Art
Gallery staffs who will be appointed as part-time faculty lecturers.
New Chairman
The plan received new impetus
recently when Dr. Adolf Katzenellenbogen .upon joining the faculty of Hopkins as chairman
of the Department of Art, gave
the plan his strong support.
Commenting on the gift Dr.
Katzenellenbogen said, "It will
provide the students a rare opportunity of experiencing in the
classroom the very characteristics of original works of art, of
different stylistic aims and various media."
In notifying Johns Hopkins of
the gift, Dr. and Mrs. Lord said
that they would contribute por-

tions of the collection in keeping with the university's ability
to display the objects, and as
they can be best adapted for the
teaching needs of the Departmerit of Fine Arts.
Doctor Lord said, "As the collection is used we hope to learn
exactly what art works should
be added so that the collection
can make the greatest contribution to the teaching of the humantties.
Permanent Name
Dr. Eisenhower stated that the
gift would be known permanently as the Dr. and Mrs. Mason
F. Lord Art Collection. "The
trustees and faculties and staff
of the university are deeply
grateful to Dr. and Mrs. Lord
for their generous contribution,
and for the continuing desire to
strengthen the fine arts here and
in the Baltimore community.
Our physical facilities for displaying this rare collection are
now woefully inadequate, but I
trust the time will come when
it, and additions to it, can be
displayed properly, not only for
students, but also for the enjoyment of the general public."
